instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the classification accuracy in the automatic classification of facial skin colour and how far can this metric go?
Output: The metric chosen to evaluate the classification accuracy in the automatic classification of facial skin colour was accuracy. The classification accuracy achieved in the testing set using the proposed approach was 89.4%, falling slightly short of the practical requirement of 90% accuracy.

instruction: What machine learning methods were used in the automatic classification of facial skin colour based on hyperspectral imaging?
Output: K-nearest neighbour, support-vector machine (SVM), decision tree, adaptive boosting, and random forest were used in the automatic classification of facial skin colour based on hyperspectral imaging.

instruction: Can the developed two-stage integrated classifier, based on hyperspectral imaging and machine learning, be used to accurately categorize the high granularity labels of facial skin-colour types used in the beauty industry?
Output: Yes, the developed two-stage integrated classifier, based on hyperspectral imaging and machine learning, can be used to accurately categorize the high granularity labels of facial skin-colour types used in the beauty industry. The study found that various machine-learning methods had advantages in categorizing different subsets of colour types. By analyzing the features of the data, it was discovered that skin chromaticity and brightness could be classified separately to provide valuable information. The two-stage integrated classifier, which combines the advantages of various machine-learning methods, achieved an accuracy of 90.4%. This classifier can be utilized by the beauty industry to evaluate the effect of skincare products on facial skin colour.
